metadata.bible_text: Implicitly the Parable of the Tenants (Matthew 21:33-46 / Mark 12:1-12 / Luke 20:9-19)
metadata.sermon_start_end: I do not relish preaching which is joined too closely to current events, since it can become merely the preacher's comment on the passing scene. On the other hand, I shudder at the thought of preaching which never comes within sight of human affairs and happenings. This is the [...] We are surrounded by poison and evil in this life; they can destroy our bodies, but 'they won't be able to kill us off.' God has others. Christians tell the world, 'They won't be able to kill us off.'

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first requirement. It does not start from a specific Bible passage but from a current event (the murder of Mrs. King). The Scripture passage is introduced only halfway through as an illustration or 'take off' point rather than the source. It treats the Bible as a repository for 'timeless' truths rather than a specific, current word.
quotes: This is the Sunday following the tragic murder... a word must be spoken.
Let me take off toward the hills and stars. There is more to 'Why murder' than I have said.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Begin with the text itself. Do not use the text to explain the event; let the text speak its own unique word that cannot be found elsewhere.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exegesis. The preacher retells the parable of the tenants in a colloquial manner without any reference to the original context, the history of Israel, or the specific theological weight of the vineyard in its biblical-theological setting. The 'Who' of the owner is treated poetically rather than exegetically.
quotes: I do not know the servant's name. Somebody said his name was Elijah or Jeremiah...
I will not call the owner's name, but I know the Man.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the original meaning of the 'vineyard' and the 'tenants' in the context of Israel's responsibility to God, using the tools of biblical scholarship as Dekker requires.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the strongest point, though it borders on social commentary. The application is extremely concrete, naming specific social ills (gun control, greed, internal community dynamics). It avoids 'general truths' by naming specific names and locations, which aligns with Dekker's demand for the 'concrete'.
quotes: Why murder in a black church committed by a black man?
We have welcomed and laughed at every crude joke, every vulgar caricature of our black churches.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: The application must flow from the specific text's unique contribution, not just from the preacher's sociological observations of the week.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is bifurcated. The first half is a sociological and psychological analysis of the murder; the second half is a 'take off' into a biblical illustration. They are not 'mixed' as Dekker demands; the hearer is not 'expounded' together with the text.
quotes: Let us move along here as on a runway before we take off toward the everlasting hills...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'runway' approach. The exposition of the Word should be the vehicle through which the contemporary situation is understood from the very first sentence.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is handled with exceptional depth and psychological realism. The preacher addresses the 'poisoned atmosphere' and the 'prison house of poverty'. Redemption is present but leans toward human resilience ('they won't be able to kill us off') rather than a purely Trinitarian act of God.
quotes: It is composed of poverty, anger, drugs, bitter talk...
God must be asked to forgive us this morning.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure redemption is clearly 'outside man' (extra nos) in Christ, rather than just the survival of the institution or the family line.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'poison' and the 'kingdom of evil', which hints at the two ways. It warns of being 'lost in time' (the destruction of society/church). However, the 'narrow way' is presented more as a communal resilience than a radical life-design choice before God.
quotes: He will pull down those evil men, and he will put other tenants in their place.
We are surrounded by poison and evil in this life; they can destroy our bodies...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher should more sharply define the 'ultimate possibilities' of the hearer's life design in response to the Word.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'Son' in the parable and as the 'Solid Rock', but he functions more as a symbol of endurance than the theological 'telos' that detaches man from himself. The doctrine of the two natures is not operative.
quotes: They took the owner's son and killed him.
On Christ the Solid Rock I stand.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Move beyond Christ as a figure in a story to Christ as the present Lord who is the only goal of the sermon.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1550 words, the sermon likely lasts 15-16 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth. It lacks the exegetical weight to sustain a 20-minute 'exposition and application'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary 'breadth' for theological depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily because it is an 'occasional' speech triggered by an event rather than an actualization of a specific Bible passage. It lacks formal exegesis and sufficient length. However, it succeeds in its concrete application and its refusal to shy away from the 'misery' of the human condition.
strengths: Concrete application: Avoids generalities by naming specific social and psychological realities.
Thematic honesty: Confronts the 'poisoned atmosphere' and human 'misery' without sugarcoating.
weaknesses: Methodological failure: The Bible is used as an illustration for an event, not as the starting point.
Lack of breadth: The duration is too short to allow for the 'sleeping' dogmatics and exegesis to properly inform the text.
Weak Christology: Christ is a character in a parable rather than the theological telos.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a powerful rhetorical address, but according to Dekker's strict formal definition, it is not a sermon. It is a 'speech about a tragic event' that utilizes a biblical keyword/story as a secondary layer. It fails the 'bicycle mechanic' test because the 'wheel' of Scripture is not properly mounted as the central axis.
